answers.answer: The medications covered by the National Health and Welfare Fund include those listed on the List of Compensated Drugs, which must first be approved by the government through a decision. These medications can only be prescribed for patients within the social health insurance system and can only be dispensed at community pharmacies that have contracts with health insurance companies.

answers.answer: Electronic prescriptions can have different durations based on the type of illness or condition. For acute conditions, they are valid for up to 7 days; for subacute conditions, they can last between 8-10 days; and for patients with chronic illnesses, they can be valid for up to 30-31 days. However, for patients with stable chronic diseases and a consistent therapeutic regimen, prescriptions may be valid for up to 90-92 days. Online prescriptions signed with an extended electronic signature can also be issued in installments for up to 30-32 days, but their overall validity remains at 92 days.
answers.bResponse: Electronic prescriptions can have different durations based on the type of illness or condition. However, for patients with stable chronic diseases and a consistent therapeutic regimen, prescriptions may be valid for up to 90-92 days. Online prescriptions signed with an extended electronic signature can also be issued in installments for up to 30-32 days, but their overall validity remains at 92 days. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/medicines

answers.answer: Yes, electronic prescriptions can be issued in installments, provided they are online, signed by the prescriber with an extended electronic signature, and have a prescribed duration of 90/91/92 days or more. These installments should not exceed a validity of 92 days after the issue date of the prescription.
